definition: to leave in stealth/to slip away

to open/to start/to turn on/to boil/to write out (a prescription, check, invoice etc)/to operate (a vehicle)/carat (gold)/abbr. for Kelvin, 開爾文|开尔文[Kai1 er3 wen2]/abbr. for 開本|开本[kai1 ben3], book format
to slip away/to escape in stealth/to skate

sentences.english: We have got into trouble here, I say we bail.
sentences.chinese: 我们闯祸了，我说咱们开溜吧。

sentences.english: Suddenly, someone said: "Maybe Wang will run away."
sentences.chinese: 说不定王常盈那小子想开溜。

sentences.english: But now the exit doors are closed and cash flow is king.
sentences.chinese: 但现在开溜的大门已经关闭，现金流主宰一切。

sentences.english: Do you still back to parents there eat a meal want to bug out?
sentences.chinese: 你是否仍然回父母家吃完饭抹完嘴就想开溜？

sentences.english: They can basically ride off into the sunset scot-free.
sentences.chinese: 他们基本上可以趁着日落开溜，逍遥法外。

sentences.english: Sometimes, mother just sloped off without being seen.
sentences.chinese: 有时候，无奈的妈妈只好偷偷地开溜出门。

sentences.english: Slip away once in a while for some private time.
sentences.chinese: 隔一段时间就开溜，获得一点个人时间。

sentences.english: The second time I took a pass in junior high I know I did the right thing.
sentences.chinese: 我第二次开溜是在初中，我知道，这回我也处理得当。

sentences.english: I didn't know whether to run.
sentences.chinese: 所有人开始转来看我，我不知道是否该开溜。

sentences.english: Jim decided to bug out, the concert was just too noisy.
sentences.chinese: 吉姆决定开溜，这音乐会太吵了。

sentences.english: The burglar outwitted the police and got away.
sentences.chinese: 那名窃贼以机智瞒过警方而开溜。

sentences.english: Till rising and gliding out I wander'd off by myself.
sentences.chinese: 直到我站起来，开溜出去，独自荡游。

definition: (coll.) to beat it/to take French leave
to escape without trace (idiom); to make one's getaway (from the scene of a crime)/to show a clean pair of heels
to run away/to take to one's heels
to flee from sth/to run away/to escape
(dialect) to rush off/to scamper off double-quick/to take to one's heels/to make oneself scarce
to take to one's heels/to scram
to escape/to flee/to run for one's life
(of a turn of events) not too encouraging/far from good/anything but reassuring
to turn on one's heels/to walk away abruptly
